pages.exhaustive_description: Khosla Ventures’ official biography page for Sven Strohband lists him as a Partner & Managing Director.  The short narrative traces his career and formative technical experiences (Volkswagen Electronics Research Lab; Stanford “Stanley” autonomous-car project; co-founder/CEO of MetaMind).  In the final paragraph it supplies the only firm academic credentials the page gives: “He holds a bachelor’s degree in mechanical engineering from Purdue University and a PhD in mechanics and computation from Stanford University.” No birth-date, birthplace, or family details are provided, but the page is an authoritative primary source for his undergraduate and doctoral degrees and their fields of study. citeturn30view0

mla_citation.page_title: Sven Strohband | Khosla Ventures
mla_citation.author_name: Khosla Ventures (corporate profile — no individual author credited)

pages.exhaustive_description: Purdue University’s Mechanical Engineering “Outstanding Mechanical Engineer Awards” page contains a scrolling list of inductees.  Line 77 explicitly reads: “SVEN STROHBAND  Partner and Managing Director, Khosla Ventures  BSME 1997,” followed by the sentence: “Sven holds a Bachelor of Science Degree in mechanical engineering from Purdue University and a PhD in mechanics and computation from Stanford University.”  These lines confirm (1) his undergraduate alma mater, (2) the exact degree (B.S. in Mechanical Engineering), and (3) the year of graduation (1997).  The page supplies no personal-life data, but it is the only publicly available university record that gives a graduation year for his bachelor’s degree. citeturn28view0

mla_citation.page_title: Outstanding Mechanical Engineer Awards – Mechanical Engineering
mla_citation.publication_name: Purdue University, School of Mechanical Engineering
mla_citation.author_name: Purdue University School of Mechanical Engineering

pages.exhaustive_description: Stanford University’s Dauskardt Group “People” profile for Sven Strohband (originally created when he was a graduate student) lists: “Education – Ph.D. Stanford University, Mechanical Engineering, 2003.”  Although the page is brief, it provides a primary-source confirmation of the year he completed his doctorate and the discipline (“Mechanical Engineering,” within Stanford’s Mechanics & Computation program).  No biographical or family information appears. citeturn23view0

mla_citation.page_title: Sven Strohband – Dauskardt Group, Stanford University

pages.exhaustive_description: Equilar ExecAtlas’s featured profile for “Sven Strohband PhD” provides an age figure (“Age 51”) along with an education section that repeats: “B.S., Purdue University – Ph.D., Stanford University.”  Because the profile is dated 11 February 2025 (see source note on the page), the stated age fixes his year of birth at approximately 1973-74, the only reliable public indicator of his birth year currently available.  The page contains no birthplace or family details, but it is the only verifiable source disclosing a birth-year proxy. citeturn29view0

mla_citation.page_title: Sven Strohband PhD – Executive Bio, Work History, and Contacts

pages.exhaustive_description: Biography entry for Sven Strohband on the Stanford Racing Team website. It says he was the lead engineer for “Stanley,” the vehicle that won the 2005 DARPA Grand Challenge; directed the Volkswagen Electronics Research Laboratory (ERL) team that designed, built, and tested Stanley’s mechanical and electronic systems; was primary liaison between Stanford and Volkswagen; remained a technical consultant for later challenges; and, in 2006, moved to Mohr Davidow Ventures.  It lists his degrees (B.S. Purdue; M.S. & Ph.D. Stanford). citeturn18view0

mla_citation.page_title: Autonomous Vehicles Designed by the Stanford Racing Team

pages.exhaustive_description: Smithsonian Magazine feature on Stanley’s historical impact.  Identifies Sven Strohband as “a lead engineer on the Stanford Racing Team” and quotes him describing Stanley’s lidar, GPS, and learned vision system.  Notes that he and teammates recognized the race was “a software race,” and details the tech architecture he helped create.  Provides 2024 context for Stanley’s museum display and the vehicle’s role in jump-starting autonomous-vehicle research. citeturn13view0

mla_citation.page_title: How a Blue SUV Named Stanley Revolutionized Driverless Car Technology

pages.exhaustive_description: Official Khosla Ventures biography.  Summarizes Strohband’s pre-VC career: six years doing technical diligence at Mohr Davidow Ventures; earlier project-management at Volkswagen ERL on LED lighting, electrochromic glass, driver-assistance systems, and robotics; lead engineer and project lead for Stanley (DARPA Grand Challenge 2005); co-founder and CEO of AI startup MetaMind (now core to Salesforce Einstein).  Also lists his Purdue B.S. and Stanford Ph.D. degrees. citeturn17view0

mla_citation.page_title: Sven Strohband | Khosla

pages.exhaustive_description: Speaker biography for the 2022 Satellite Innovation conference.  Reiterates that before venture capital, Strohband led technical projects at Volkswagen ERL, was lead engineer for Stanford’s Stanley, and co-founded/served as CEO of MetaMind (now part of Salesforce Einstein).  Confirms technical-project scope (LED lighting, electrochromic glass, driver-assistance, robotics) and lists his academic credentials. citeturn16view0

mla_citation.page_title: Dr. Sven Strohband – 2022 Satellite Innovation

pages.exhaustive_description: Press-release announcing MetaMind’s launch and $8 million seed round.  Names Sven Strohband as MetaMind’s CEO (and CTO at Khosla Ventures); includes his quote on scaling deep-learning solutions for text and image data; details MetaMind’s platform capabilities and initial customer traction.  Establishes him as co-founder and operational leader of the startup before its later exit to Salesforce. citeturn6view0

mla_citation.page_title: MetaMind Launches State-of-the-Art AI Platform Bringing Automated Predictions and Smarter Decision-Making to Businesses

pages.exhaustive_description: VentureBeat launch story.  Reports that Strohband “has joined MetaMind as its chief executive,” describes his collaboration with Richard Socher, shows photograph of both co-founders, notes the 10-employee headcount, and quotes Strohband on democratizing deep learning.  Provides concrete evidence of his CEO/operator role outside VC. citeturn15view0

mla_citation.page_title: Deep-learning Startup MetaMind Launches With $8 M From Benioff & Khosla Ventures

pages.exhaustive_description: Recode/Vox article on MetaMind’s seed round.  Quotes Strohband (identified as MetaMind CEO) explaining the “drag, drop and learn” interface and his move from Khosla Ventures into an operating role.  Confirms $8 million backing from Khosla Ventures and Marc Benioff and that the company had 10 employees four months after founding. citeturn14view0

mla_citation.page_title: MetaMind Sets Out to Bring Deep Learning to the Rest of Us

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch author-bio page for Sven Strohband.  Summarizes his Volkswagen ERL projects, role as lead engineer on Stanley, co-founder/CEO of MetaMind (now part of Salesforce Einstein), and board seats.  Serves as a concise compilation of his non-VC operating history. citeturn21view0

mla_citation.page_title: Sven Strohband – Author at TechCrunch

pages.exhaustive_description: FinSMEs funding note.  States that MetaMind was “founded in 2014 by CEO Sven Strohband and CTO Richard Socher,” confirms the $8 million round from Khosla Ventures and Marc Benioff, and lists examples of MetaMind’s product modules and early industry use-cases.  Reinforces Strohband’s founder/CEO role. citeturn20search2

mla_citation.page_title: MetaMind Raises $8 M in Funding

pages.exhaustive_description: Official biography on the Khosla Ventures website.  The page states that Sven Strohband is “Partner and Managing Director at Khosla Ventures,” and that he “led the firm’s early investments in Berkshire Grey, GitLab, Hermeus and Rocket Lab, among others.”  It summarizes the venture-capital portion of his career as follows:  (1) current role – Partner & Managing Director at Khosla Ventures; (2) prior VC role – six years at Mohr Davidow Ventures, where he “led technical diligence for the infrastructure IT and sustainability practices” and helped portfolio companies with talent, product-market-fit experiments and fundraising strategy.  The biography also lists representative sectors and themes he backs—robotics, AI, novel user-experience technologies—and names numerous board seats (Berkshire Grey, Rocket Lab, Velo3D, Waabi, ThoughtSpot, etc.), illustrating both his sector focus (frontier tech/AI/robotics/space) and hands-on board involvement.  Non-VC portions (Volkswagen, Stanford “Stanley,” MetaMind) are included for chronology/context but the page’s only venture-capital dates are implicit (no explicit years).

mla_citation.page_title: Sven Strohband | Khosla

pages.exhaustive_description: Excerpt from Rocket Lab USA, Inc.’s definitive proxy statement (DEF 14A) filed with the U.S. SEC.  Under the Board-biographies section, it provides a detailed, date-specific timeline of Strohband’s venture-capital career:  • “Since May 2018” – Managing Director, Khosla Ventures • “since November 2012” – Partner and CTO, Khosla Ventures • “2006 to 2012” – Partner and later CTO, Mohr Davidow Ventures.  It also confirms that he has served on Rocket Lab’s board since 2013 and adds that he joined Berkshire Grey’s board in 2021.  The filing therefore establishes exact entry points, promotions and titles across two venture firms and corroborates his deep-tech investment focus (Berkshire Grey: robotics/AI; Rocket Lab: space).

mla_citation.page_title: Rocket Lab USA, Inc. Notice of 2023 Annual Meeting and Proxy Statement (DEF 14A)

pages.exhaustive_description: FinSMEs funding brief announcing Idibon’s $1.4 million seed round (16 Apr 2013).  It notes that “Sven Strohband, Partner and CTO at Khosla Ventures, will join Idibon’s board of directors.”  Although terse, the item is important because it provides a near-contemporaneous, third-party confirmation that as of April 2013 Strohband already held the dual title of Partner & CTO at Khosla Ventures and that he actively represented the firm on portfolio company boards—evidence of his functional role inside the partnership shortly after joining (late 2012) and of his thematic focus on natural-language AI startups.

mla_citation.page_title: “Idibon Raises $1.4M from Khosla Ventures.”

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch Live event recap (12 May 2022) covering mobility startup Waabi.  The article identifies Raquel Urtasun’s Waabi Series A and states that the “Series A lead investor Sven Strohband from Khosla Ventures” joined the livestream.  This demonstrates (a) that Strohband personally leads large (‘monster’) rounds, (b) that autonomous-vehicle / deep-AI mobility is a current investment theme for him, and (c) that he represents Khosla Ventures publicly as the lead partner on such deals—useful for illustrating his present-day sector focus and investment philosophy of backing AI-first, deep-tech companies at significant scale.

mla_citation.page_title: “Watch the Latest TechCrunch Live Here: Raising Monster Rounds for Self-Driving Mobility Startups.”

pages.exhaustive_description: Speaker biography on the 2022 Satellite Innovation conference website.  Repeats that Strohband is “Partner and Managing Director at Khosla Ventures” and credits him with leading early investments in Berkshire Grey, GitLab, Hermeus and Rocket Lab—reinforcing his deep-tech/space/AI investment themes.  It also reiterates his six-year tenure at Mohr Davidow Ventures conducting technical diligence and portfolio support, underscoring the skill set he brought when entering venture capital.  The page’s emphasis on space and robotics (context of a satellite conference) further illustrates his thematic focus on frontier hardware and aerospace.  No years are given, but the information independently corroborates the positions detailed in other sources.

mla_citation.page_title: “Dr. Sven Strohband – 2022 Satellite Innovation.”

pages.exhaustive_description: GitLab’s corporate blog post (published September 17 2015) formally announces that GitLab has closed a $4 million Series A round led by Khosla Ventures.  The post confirms that the money follows a July 2015 seed round, states that the capital will be used to “accelerate growth and scale global operations,” and quotes Vinod Khosla praising GitLab’s open-source model.  No other investors nor valuation are disclosed, but the entry establishes Sven Strohband/Khosla Ventures as the lead for GitLab’s Series A.

mla_citation.page_title: GitLab announces $4M Series A funding from Khosla Ventures

pages.exhaustive_description: GitLab’s press-release (dated October 13 2021) details pricing and launch of the company’s Nasdaq IPO.  It sets the offer at $77 per share for 10.4 million shares and notes trading will begin 14 Oct 2021 under ticker GTLB.  This source provides the exit outcome (public listing) for the earlier Khosla-backed investment.

mla_citation.page_title: GitLab Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering

pages.exhaustive_description: Rocket Lab newsroom item announcing it “Secures A-Round Funding from Khosla Ventures.”  Though the exact dollar figure is not disclosed, the post confirms Khosla Ventures (partner: Sven Strohband) as sole investor for the Series A (dated October 1 2013 in accompanying Crunchbase data) and states funds will launch the company’s orbital-launch-vehicle program aimed at small-satellite markets.

mla_citation.page_title: Rocket Lab Secures A-Round Funding from Khosla Ventures

pages.exhaustive_description: Rocket Lab press release (August 25 2021) announcing completion of its SPAC merger with Vector Acquisition Corp.  It states common stock will trade on Nasdaq under RKLB beginning August 25 2021 and lists $777 million in gross proceeds—defining the public-company outcome of Khosla’s early investment.

mla_citation.page_title: Rocket Lab Completes Merger with Vector Acquisition Corporation to Become Publicly Traded End-to-End Space Company

pages.exhaustive_description: Berkshire Grey press release (January 21 2020) discloses a $263 million Series B.  It lists SoftBank, Khosla Ventures (partner Sven Strohband), NEA and Canaan as participants, providing the round size, date and investor roster.

mla_citation.page_title: Berkshire Grey Raises $263 Million Series B Financing

pages.exhaustive_description: Business Wire release (July 21 2021) announces Berkshire Grey’s completed business combination with Revolution Acceleration Acquisition Corp.  It confirms trading of Class A shares on Nasdaq under ticker BGRY starting July 22 2021, documenting the exit (de-SPAC IPO) of the Khosla-backed company.

mla_citation.page_title: Berkshire Grey Completes Business Combination with Revolution Acceleration Acquisition Corp and Will Begin Trading on Nasdaq Under the Symbol “BGRY”

pages.exhaustive_description: Crunchbase funding-round profile (announced June 3 2015) lists Velo3D’s Series A: $22.1 million, led solely by Khosla Ventures with partner Sven Strohband noted.  It provides the exact amount, date and lead-investor attribution.

mla_citation.page_title: Series A – Velo3D

pages.exhaustive_description: Velo3D press release (September 29 2021) reports completion of its merger with JAWS Spitfire SPAC.  It states common stock will begin NYSE trading under ticker VLD on Sept 30 2021 and that the deal delivers $274 million in net proceeds, confirming the public-company exit.

mla_citation.page_title: Velo3D Completes Merger with JAWS Spitfire Acquisition Corporation to Become a Publicly-Traded, Additive Manufacturing Technology Company

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch article (October 29 2020) reports Hermeus’ $16 million Series A.  It notes the round was led by Canaan Partners and included continued participation from Khosla Ventures, Bling Capital and Revolution’s Rise of the Rest.  The story details planned use of funds to build and ground-test a full-scale Mach-5 engine.

mla_citation.page_title: Supersonic aircraft startup Hermeus raises $16 million Series A

pages.exhaustive_description: CNBC report (March 10 2022) covers Hermeus’ $100 million Series B, led by Sam Altman with participation from Founders Fund, In-Q-Tel and existing investors Khosla Ventures, Canaan Partners and Bling Capital.  The piece explains that the capital will fund completion of the Quarterhorse prototype and subsequent aircraft development, evidencing the follow-on round outcome.

mla_citation.page_title: Hypersonic aircraft start-up Hermeus raises $100 million

pages.exhaustive_description: The Verge feature (June 8 2021) announces Waabi’s emergence from stealth with an $83.5 million Series A led by Khosla Ventures and joined by Uber and Aurora.  It confirms the amount, round type, lead investor and date, and describes Waabi’s focus on autonomous trucking.

mla_citation.page_title: Waabi, the rare autonomous vehicle startup with a woman CEO, raises $83.5 million

pages.exhaustive_description: Waabi corporate blog / Globe Newswire release (June 18 2024) announces an oversubscribed $200 million Series B led by Uber and Khosla Ventures with strategic investors NVIDIA, Volvo, Porsche SE, Scania and others.  It states the funding lifts total capital to $280 million and will finance deployment of fully driverless trucks in 2025.

mla_citation.page_title: Waabi Raises $200M USD to Launch Fully Driverless Trucks in 2025

pages.exhaustive_description: ThoughtSpot press release (June 18 2014) announces a $30 million Series B round led by Khosla Ventures.  It highlights search-driven analytics technology, adds that Khosla partner Keith Rabois will join the board, and states proceeds will expand engineering and go-to-market teams.

mla_citation.page_title: ThoughtSpot Raises $30 Million in an Oversubscribed Series B Round

pages.exhaustive_description: PR Newswire release (December 5 2014) announces MetaMind’s public launch and its $8 million seed round funded by Khosla Ventures and Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff.  It describes MetaMind’s deep-learning platform and early benchmark performance, and identifies Sven Strohband as co-founder.

mla_citation.page_title: MetaMind Launches State-of-the-Art AI Platform Bringing Automated Predictions and Smarter Decision-Making to Businesses

pages.exhaustive_description: TechCrunch news brief (April 4 2016) reports Salesforce’s acquisition of MetaMind.  It confirms the deal, quotes CEO Richard Socher on integrating deep-learning into Salesforce products, and marks the exit outcome for the Khosla-backed company.

mla_citation.page_title: Salesforce acquires MetaMind

pages.exhaustive_description: The BestStartup US list article (published May 12 2022) contains a short biographical entry for Sven Strohband (scroll lines 126-131).  In addition to summarizing his career, it states:  “In his spare time, Sven enjoys teaching his kids to code, flying autonomous drones and cycling.”  From this we learn (1) he is a parent with more than one child (“kids”) and (2) three leisure-time hobbies—coding with his children, autonomous-drone flying and cycling.  No spouse or philanthropic details appear on the page.

mla_citation.page_title: Meet United States’s 101 Top Managing Directors in the Finance Space

pages.exhaustive_description: The public Instalker mirror of Sven Strohband’s Twitter profile (accessed July 25 2025) shows his self-written bio line: “Khosla Ventures. Passionate about building things. Coding enthusiast. Dad. Biker. Welder in my spare time.”  Personal-life takeaways:  • He identifies himself as a “Dad,” confirming that he has children.  • Additional hobbies: biking (he calls himself a “Biker”) and welding (“Welder in my spare time”).  These hobbies complement those listed in the BestStartup entry; together they give a fuller picture of his leisure interests.

mla_citation.page_title: Sven Strohband @SStrohband – Twitter Profile

pages.exhaustive_description: NextBigWhat’s free written summary of the podcast episode “What AI is Making Possible | Ilya Sutskever and Sven Strohband” (posted July 22 2023) records direct quotation attributed to Strohband: “These challenges are big, but if you manage to overcome them, it is so worthwhile because then we could create truly unbelievable lives for ourselves that are completely unimaginable.”  The surrounding text shows he is discussing the societal upsides of safely harnessing super-intelligent AI.  This reveals a documented public stance: he is an AI optimist who believes solving AI-alignment challenges can yield dramatic quality-of-life improvements.  While primarily professional, it is a personal philosophical position on a major social issue.

mla_citation.page_title: What AI is Making Possible | Ilya Sutskever and Sven Strohband | Free Podcast Summary
